entry_title: Alyssa Naeher retires: Who will take over in goal for USWNT after USA women's legend bows out?
entry_summary: She may have returned the USWNT to the top of the global football hierarchy by winning the Olympic gold medal, but Emma Hayes has a significant new task on her hands as 2024 comes to a close.
entry_content: Kyle Bonn She may have returned the USWNT to the top of the global football hierarchy by winning the Olympic gold medal, but Emma Hayes has a significant new task on her hands as the 2024 year comes to a close. The future of the goalkeeper position for the United States, a position of enormous strength over the decades, now faces uncertainty as 36-year-old legend Alyssa Naeher surprisingly announced her international retirement in late November. It came as a shock to USWNT fans as Naeher told the world she would hang up her international boots following upcoming friendlies against England and the Netherlands. Naeher's reveal was even more surprising given her NWSL club, the Chicago Red Stars, had just announced days prior that she would remain with the team for 2025 following a one-year extension of her contract. Now, as the calendar turns over and Emma Hayes looks towards the future, Naeher will add herself to the list of past USWNT greats like Hope Solo and Briana Scurry, while the team searches for the next great between the sticks. At 36, Alyssa Naeher retires as a legend of the international game. She made her debut in 2014 and upon her retirement, has logged 113 international caps with the potential for two more against England and the Netherlands. Naeher is the only goalkeeper in women's soccer history to keep a clean sheet in both the Women's World Cup final and an Olympic gold medal match, winning the World Cup title in 2015 and 2019 and a gold medal at the 2024 Olympics, plus the bronze in 2020. On an individual level, Naeher won NWSL Goalkeeper of the Year in 2014 and CONCACAF Goalkeeper of the Year in 2018. Thus, the former Penn State standout is one of the most decorated goalkeepers in the global game. We’re gonna miss watching Alyssa Naeher making big saves in clutch moments for the USWNT 🥹🇺🇸Congrats on retirement, Alyssa 🙌 pic.twitter.com/G7qQxWUiiu “Having the opportunity to be a part of the USWNT for the past 15 years has been the greatest honor,” said Naeher in the official press release. “When I began this journey, I never could have imagined where it would take me, and now I find myself so grateful for all the incredible teammates that I have shared the field with; teammates that have turned into lifelong friends. To all my teammates, coaches and staff, thank you all for pushing me, supporting me, and making me a better person/player every single day. A special thanks goes to my family. You have traveled all over the world and were in my corner every step of the way and I love you all. “This has been a special team to be a part of and I am beyond proud of what we have achieved both on and off the field. The memories I have made over the years will last me a lifetime. I know one chapter is ending, but I am so excited to continue to see the growth of this team going forward and what more they can accomplish.” The Sporting News looks over the top candidates to replace Naeher in goal for the foreseeable future. At 28, Casey Murphy has been the backup to Alyssa Naeher for quite some time now. During Vlatko Andonovski's tenure, the former USWNT head coach made a point to give Murphy time on the pitch, noting publicly on numerous occasions how important it was for Murphy to get time in the national team system should she need to be called upon in a competitive environment. Yet of her 20 international caps dating back to late 2021, Murphy has only been deployed in six competitive matches, and none at either a World Cup or Olympic games. She saw the field in the 2022 CONCACAF W Championship for three games and has made three other SheBelieves Cup appearances. A two-time Big 10 Goalkeeper of the Year with Rutgers and a two-time NWSL Challenge Cup winner with the NC Courage, Murphy probably has the inside track to secure the long-term spot for herself. Yet due to her relative international experience and a few talented younger possibilities on the radar, it's by no means a sure thing that Hayes will hand Murphy the job. Not listed on the November roster for the European matches, the USWNT coaching staff could be thinking elsewhere. 2024 has been a year of rising stock for 28-year-old Phallon Tullis-Joyce, who before now hadn't been on the USWNT radar. Then, two things happened to vault the former Miami Hurricane into contention for the long-term starting job with the national team. First, she moved to Manchester United in September of last year to back up Mary Earps. Then, the following summer, Earps departed for PSG. Now, Tullis-Joyce is the starter for a Women's Super League contender, which lands her squarely in Emma Hayes' sights. She's been fantastic in the job, conceding just three goals in her first eight games, and has earned her first international call-up for Naeher's European swansong in late November. She likely won't see the field with Naeher getting her final show, so can she impress enough in training to warrant future communications from Hayes? The youngest of the likely options for the immediate future, Mandy Haught has risen meteorically like the aforementioned Tullis-Joyce. Winning ACC Goalkeeper of the Year twice at Virginia Tech wasn't enough to vault her into the senior national team conversation with more experienced options available, but winning the NWSL championship last year with NJ/NY Gotham FC seemed to raise enough eyebrows. After moving to the Utah Royals this season and logging a strong xG differential on an attack-deficient team, which earned her a nomination for NWSL Goalkeeper of the Year (quite the feat for a keeper on a non-playoff team), she has finally been brought into the fold. After being called up for the first time in October and getting her first start in a clean sheet performance against Argentina, she's again been included for Naeher's swansong in Europe. A former four-year starter at a top collegiate program Stanford, Campbell was selected in 2017 by the Houston Dash and has been with the NWSL side ever since, winning the league's Goalkeeper of the Year award in 2023. She has been part of the senior national team picture since 2013 and won a bronze medal with the squad in 2020, but has only seen the field eight times, largely considered third-choice behind a mix of Alyssa Naeher, Ashlynn Harris, and Casey Murphy. With the Dash struggling to a last-place finish in the 2024 season, Campbell has fallen out of the picture, but could a seismic shift in the depth charge change things up? If Emma Hayes is looking for a younger player to mold for a longer-term solution to bring consistency to a position that has long belonged to just a few legendary players, she could turn to some young NWSL stars or even to the collegiate ranks. Beyond Haught and Campbell, the NWSL is somewhat devoid of American standout goalkeepers (German star Ann-Katrin Berger and England-born Anna Moorhouse were two of the three 2024 Goalkeeper of the Year nominees alongside Haught). Aubrey Kingsbury is the most obvious candidate, coming up just a game short of the NWSL title this season, but the former Wake Forest star is now 33 and has been behind many of the aforementioned names on the depth chart for years now. Bella Bixby of the Portland Thorns is also 29 without a USWNT senior call-up in her career. Claudia Dickey, still just 24, was a standout at UNC and has been on the fringes of the national team conversation, but her Seattle Reign conceded the most goals in the league this season. At the collegiate ranks, Mia Justus of Texas is the cousin of former USMNT standout Tim Howard and won a national championship as a backup with Florida State before transferring. She's long been a U.S. youth international and was named to the Mac Hermann Award watch list alongside Emily Puricelli, who has much less recognition at the U.S. youth level but was exceptional for St. Louis this season, logging a .861 save percentage and conceding just 11 goals in 23 games this year, putting her in the conversation for best in the nation. Kyle Bonn, is a Syracuse University broadcast journalism graduate with over a decade of experience covering soccer globally. Kyle specializes in soccer tactics and betting, with a degree in data analytics. Kyle also does TV broadcasts for Wake Forest soccer, and has had previous stops with NBC Soccer and IMG College. When not covering the game, he has long enjoyed loyalty to the New York Giants, Yankees, and Fulham. Kyle enjoys playing racquetball and video games when not watching or covering sports.

entry_title: Phillies predicted to land $88 million slugger in offseason blockbuster
entry_summary: The Philadelphia Phillies are expected to be aggressive this winter after a disappointing postseason in 2024. They could target outfielders who can bring more power to their lineup.
entry_content: Aaliyan Mohammed The Philadelphia Phillies are expected to be aggressive this winter after a disappointing postseason in 2024. They could target outfielders who can bring more power to their lineup. While making offseason predictions, theScore predicted that the Phillies would sign Baltimore Orioles slugger Anthony Santander in free agency. "He also inks Anthony Santander, whose 44 home runs last season matched the output of outfielders Nick Castellanos, Brandon Marsh, and Austin Hays," theScore wrote of Dave Dombrowski while predicting his many free agent moves. "Santander has some warts, and the defensive fit isn't perfect with Castellanos and Kyle Schwarber also on the roster, but Philadelphia needs to add to the team to get the most out of a title window." Santander hit 44 home runs in 2024 and was named an All-Star for the first time in his career. Spotrac projects him to sign a five-year, $88 million deal in free agency. He can play either of the corner outfield spots. The Phillies ranked 20th with a .610 OPS from center field last season. Signing Santander could allow them to move Brandon Marsh to center field full-time, allowing Santander to play left field. Even though Marsh struggled at the end of the year, he would still be an upgrade in center field. Adding Santander would ultimately give them three outfielders they can rely on every day. The Phillies ranked 22nd in home runs from the right side of the plate. Santander is a switch hitter but could bring some power from that side of the dish. He hit 12 of his home runs as a right-handed hitter last year. More MLB: Phillies predicted to sign $131 million All-Star in offseason blockbuster Aaliyan Mohammed is a sports journalist who graduated from Mississippi State University. He covered MLB prospects for MLB.com. He has also spent time covering the Green Bay Packers as well as college sports in the SEC. His work features interviews with Gilbert Brown, Andre Rison, Mike Leach and multiple MLB executives.

entry_title: Lions injury updates: Amon-Ra St. Brown, David Montgomery, Carlton Davis, more
entry_summary: The Detroit Lions released their first injury report of the week on Monday, which was an estimation because the team only held a walkthrough. Here are some injury updates on wide receiver Amon-Ra St. Brown, cornerback Carlton Davis, running back David Montgomery, and more.
entry_content: Mike Moraitis Junfu Han / USA TODAY NETWORK via Imagn Images With the Detroit Lions set to play against the Chicago Bears on Thursday this week, the team released its first injury report on Monday and a total of six players did not take part in practice. The injury report was an estimation, as the Lions only held a walkthrough. The six players who did not take part are cornerback Carlton Davis (knee, thumb), left tackle Taylor Decker (knee), running back David Montgomery (shoulder), wide receiver Kalif Raymond (foot), defensive lineman D.J. Reader (illness) and wide receiver Amon-Ra St. Brown (knee). The only player listed on the initial injury report as a full participant was cornerback Terrion Arnold (groin), who missed the Week 12 game against the Indianapolis Colts. The estimated full session puts Arnold on track to return in Week 13. After practice, head coach Dan Campbell addressed the media and revealed that of those aforementioned six players, Decker, Davis and Raymond have a chance to sit out the Thanksgiving contest against Chicago. Dan Campbell says there may be three of the guys listed below who could miss this week: Decker, Davis, Raymond.Says St. Brown is a little banged up, too. https://t.co/Gak7b9Q1ho St. Brown was the only real surprise on the injury report, but knowing how tough he is, it would take an act of God to prevent him from playing. "Saint is a little banged up," Campbell said. "We'll see how he recovers." Campbell also noted  he doesn't think most of the injuries will be long-term issues. After the game on Sunday, Campbell said Raymond was likely to miss time. Raymond, Davis, Decker and Montgomery all exited Sunday's contest due to injury, but Decker was able to return to the game. Montgomery said he could have returned but was held out as a precaution and he expects to suit up on Thursday. Decker was also positive about his outlook. On top of his duties with Sporting News, Mike is the managing editor and lead writer for Titans Wire.

entry_title: Cardinals urged to sign Super Bowl winning OG in 2025
entry_summary: Arizona bolsters their offensive line in this scenario.
entry_content: Andrew Parsaud The NFC West is still an extremely close race after 12 weeks. The Arizona Cardinals held a slim lead over the division for multiple weeks, but surrendered it with their loss to the Seattle Seahawks on Sunday. The Cardinals and Seahawks are both 6-5 (Seattle holds the tiebreaker) while the Los Angeles Rams and San Francisco 49ers are right behind at 5-6. There's still time for the Cardinals to make a playoff push, but there's a way they can ensure this close of a battle doesn't happen next year. Bleacher Report has the Cardinals going out and signing Kansas City Chiefs guard Trey Smith in the offseason to protect Kyler Murray. Arizona is projected to have $98 million in effective cap space next offseason, which means general manager Monti Ossenfort can splurge. He should take a long look at Kansas City Chiefs guard Trey Smith, the second-ranked player on the Bleacher Report 2025 free agent board. Smith has become a strong foundational piece of the Chiefs offense and a catalyst in the ground game. He could do the same for Arizona, which is establishing itself as a run-first team. This would be a solid move that will pay dividends for years to come in Arizona. Andrew Parsaud is a recent graduate of Penn State, where he studied digital journalism and media. entry_title: When is England vs. USWNT game? Date, time of international friendly between Lionesses and USA women
entry_summary: A highly anticipated return for Emma Hayes to her hometown will see the former Chelsea head coach lead FIFA's No. 1-ranked USA women's side into enemy territory as they meet England at Wembley Stadium for a friendly.
entry_content: Kyle Bonn A highly anticipated return for Emma Hayes to her hometown will see the former Chelsea head coach lead FIFA's No. 1-ranked USA women's side into enemy territory as they meet England at Wembley Stadium for a friendly. It will be an emotional homecoming for Hayes, but the match will be about much more than just her return to London. Both sides are nursing injures to key attacking players, which presents an opportunity to give young stars an opportunity to shine. While the USWNT will be without its three-headed monster up front, England head coach Sarina Wiegman also must develop a plan to cover for a number of absentees. The United States will be looking for revenge from their last trip to England's most famous venue, where they fell 2-1 in October of 2022 in a tightly contested match that served as a harbinger of things to come for both nations. The victory announced the Lionesses, recent European champions that previous summer, as contenders for the following year's Women's World Cup, where they would go on to reach the final. Meanwhile, the U.S. would suffer their worst-ever Women's World Cup performance Down Under. Now that they've recovered by winning gold at the Olympics this year, the U.S. will hope to prove they're still the team to beat globally. MORE: A full overview of the USWNT squad to face England and the Netherlands This eagerly anticipated international friendly kicks off from Wembley Stadium on Saturday, November 30 at 5:20 p.m. local time in London, England. Here's how that time translates across some of the major territories around the globe: This international friendly will be televised in English on TNT in the United States. You can stream TNT live on Sling, as well as on Turner's dedicated streaming platform Max. A Spanish-language broadcast is also available on both Telemundo and Universo. Those two channels are accessible to stream on Fubo or NBC's dedicated platform Peacock. Fubo are offering a free trial for new users. For a limited time, you can get your first month of Fubo for as low as $59.99, a $20 savings. Stream ESPN, ABC, CBS, Fox, NBC and 200+ top channels of live TV and sports without cable. (Participating plans only. Taxes and fees may apply). The match from Wembley will be broadcast domestically on ITV1 in England, as well as STV in Scotland. Both of those providers will also stream the match on their own dedicated streaming platforms. England suffered a major blow just days ago as Lauren Hemp tore her ACL, adding to the attacking injuries the Lionesses have been forced to weather. Also sidelined are Ella Toone and Lauren James, who both sustained calf injuries in recent weeks but shouldn't be out much longer. With Rachel Daly having retired from international football this year, that leaves Beth Mead to carry the front line along with Chloe Kelly and Alessia Russo. England predicted XI (4-3-3, right to left): Earps (GK) — Bronze, Bright, Williamson, Carter — Stanway, Kirby, Walsh — Mead, Russo, Kelly Goalkeepers: Mary Earps, Hannah Hampton, Anna Moorhouse Defenders: Millie Bright, Lucy Bronze, Jess Carter, Gabby George, Alex Greenwood, Maya Le Tissier, Esme Morgan, Millie Turner, Leah Williamson Midfielders: Laura Brown, Grace Clinton, Fran Kirby, Ruby Mace, Jess Park, Georgia Stanway, Keira Walsh Forwards: Aggie Beever-Jones, Chloe Kelly, Beth Mead, Jessica Naz, Alessia Russo MORE: All the latest EPL club news | Team-by-team Premier League schedule for 2024/25 | Latest Premier League top scorer rankings Head coach Hayes will have to do without any of the world-class three-pronged front line, as Sophia Smith, Trinity Rodman, and Mallory Swanson were all left at home. U.S. Soccer cited "nagging injuries" for the trio, but it appears that it's nothing more than rest for them after a long season, especially Rodman who missed last the last two international breaks with a back injury and played in the NWSL final the weekend before with her club. That leaves the forward line extremely thin, as only Lynn Williams (20) and Jaedyn Shaw (eight) have more than one international goal to their name. Also missing is Crystal Dunn, who has been absent for club or country for weeks due to personal reasons. Alex Morgan has retired, while both Mia Fishel and Croix Bethune are out with long-term knee injuries. Goalkeeper Alyssa Naeher will make her international swan song in this international break, with this game or the ensuing one against the Netherlands serving as her final USWNT appearance before retiring from U.S. duty. USA predicted XI (4-3-3, right to left): Naeher (GK) — Fox, Girma, Sonnett, Nighswonger — Lavelle, Hershfelt, Horan — L. Williams, Shaw, Thompson Goalkeepers: Mandy Haught, Alyssa Naeher, Phallon Tullis-Joyce Defenders: Tierna Davidson, Emily Fox, Eva Gaetino, Naomi Girma, Casey Krueger, Alyssa Malonson, Jenna Nighswonger, Emily Sams, Emily Sonnett Midfielders: Korbin Albert, Sam Coffey, Hal Hershfelt, Lindsey Horan, Rose Lavelle, Lily Yohannes Forwards: Yazmeen Ryan, Emma Sears, Ally Sentnor, Jaedyn Shaw, Alyssa Thompson, Lynn Williams If you purchase a product or register for an account through one of the links on our site, we may receive compensation.  Learn more >  Kyle Bonn, is a Syracuse University broadcast journalism graduate with over a decade of experience covering soccer globally. Kyle specializes in soccer tactics and betting, with a degree in data analytics. Kyle also does TV broadcasts for Wake Forest soccer, and has had previous stops with NBC Soccer and IMG College. When not covering the game, he has long enjoyed loyalty to the New York Giants, Yankees, and Fulham. Kyle enjoys playing racquetball and video games when not watching or covering sports.

entry_title: USWNT roster for December friendlies vs. England, Netherlands: USA women squad with Smith, Swanson, Rodman out
entry_summary: The "Triple Espresso" trio of Mallory Swanson, Sophia Smith, and Trinity Rodman have all been left off the USA women's roster for December friendlies against England and the Netherlands.
entry_content:
Kyle Bonn The USWNT could feature a bit of an unfamiliar look as Emma Hayes gears up for an emotional and highly-anticipated return to her home nation for a friendly against England plus another European visit to the Netherlands this December. Lacking their prolific attacking trio of Sophia Smith, Mallory Swanson, and Trinity Rodman, the U.S. women will bring a number of promising young stars with them on the trip across the pond. Having returned to the world's No. 1 rank following this past summer's Olympic gold medal, the USWNT face world No. 2 Lionesses on November 30 followed shortly by another truly top-tier matchup against the 11th-ranked Dutch. 



STREAM:USMNT and USWNT international friendlies LIVE on Sling




 STREAM:USMNT and USWNT international friendlies LIVE on Sling Hayes, a London-born coaching great who led Chelsea for years before joining U.S. Soccer less than a year ago, will take charge of two post-Thanksgiving matches starting with one in her home city. The Sporting News brings you all the info regarding the absence of the famed attacking trio as well as the fresh faces in the squad. MORE: USWNT schedule, results, highlights from matches across 2024 year Emma Hayes has called in 22 players to the U.S. women's national team squad to play England and The Netherlands in early December. There are a host of new faces thanks to the absence of a few key veterans, but captain Lindsey Horan still provides a veteran presence alongside Rose Lavelle and Naomi Girma. Goalkeeper Alyssa Naeher will make her final appearances for the USWNT in these fixtures, as she will retire from international duty after the two games. MORE: Why Lily Yohannes committed to the United States over the Netherlands The trio of USWNT attacking stars, Mallory Swanson, Trinity Rodman, and Sophia Smith are all absent from the roster for December fixtures against England and the Netherlands. Nicknamed "Triple Espresso," the three world-class forwards are all dealing with "nagging injuries" according to U.S. Soccer, and were thus rested for this month to give them a full offseason. Rodman's injury is most well-documented, as she missed the previous trio of friendlies against Iceland and Argentina due to a back problem suffered while on club duty with Washington Spirit. She returned for club matches at the end of the NWSL regular season and playoffs, but has been given a chance to rest. Injuries to Sophia Smith and Mallory Swanson are less clear. Swanson missed a year due to a serious knee injury that kept her out of the 2023 Women's World Cup, and could be feeling the effects of wear and tear following her return. Smith, meanwhile, missed matches in September and October due to an ankle injury, and maybe has been rested due to lingering effects of such. Given the team's careful dancing around nagging injuries, it's a bit surprising that Rose Lavelle is included on the roster. The 29-year-old has dealt with a lingering knee complaint for the past few years and may have been keen to get some additional rest. Also still missing is Cat Macario, who remains less than 100% in her slow but steady recovery from an ACL tear. New Chelsea head coach Sonia Bompastor said in October that Macario was still working her way back from this exceedingly long injury issue, even though she has been a consistent option off the bench. However, Emma Hayes confirmed that both Macario and Mia Fishel, who is out with a torn ACL, are invited to the team's Thanksgiving dinner they will hold in England before the friendly. Thanks to the absences on the USWNT roster this December, a number of unfamiliar faces dot the roster. In for the first time since confirming her USWNT commitment is 17-year-old Lily Yohannes, who affirmed her decision to represent the United States back in early November. Uncapped players on the roster this international break include Manchester United goalkeeper Phallon Tullis-Joyce and Utah Royals forward Ally Sentnor. 28-year-old Tullis-Joyce, who hails from New York City and played collegiately for Miami, has been the Red Devils starter this season after Mary Earps departed for PSG. Sentnor, meanwhile, was the No. 1 overall draft pick by the Utah Royals a year ago out of North Carolina, scoring three goals and assisting four others in her first NWSL season. Alyssa Thompson is also back for another international camp after grabbing her first USWNT goal against Iceland last month, and left-back Alyssa Malonson hopes to earn her second cap after making her debut against Argentina in October. The two December friendlies for the USWNT will both be contested abroad, with a game against England at Wembley Stadium first on Saturday, November 30 followed by the match against the Netherlands three days later in The Hague. Both games will be televised in the English on TNT, with the England match also on truTV. Both channels are available to stream on Sling as well as Turner's dedicated platform Max. In Spanish, the two matches will also be televised on Universo and Telemundo. Those two channels are available to stream on Fubo, who are offering a free trial for new users. The games are also available to stream on NBC's dedicated platform Peacock. Kyle Bonn, is a Syracuse University broadcast journalism graduate with over a decade of experience covering soccer globally. Kyle specializes in soccer tactics and betting, with a degree in data analytics. Kyle also does TV broadcasts for Wake Forest soccer, and has had previous stops with NBC Soccer and IMG College. When not covering the game, he has long enjoyed loyalty to the New York Giants, Yankees, and Fulham. Kyle enjoys playing racquetball and video games when not watching or covering sports.

entry_title: Top 25 high school girls basketball rankings: No. 2 Ontario Christian knocks off Etiwanda
entry_summary: High school girls basketball season is barely underway, but the top four has already rearranged itself – including a new No. 1 team in the country.
entry_content: Lance Smith Nicole Mullen/Arizona Republic / USA Today Network/ Imagn High school girls basketball season is barely underway, but the top four has already rearranged itself – and there's a new No. 1 team in the country.Here are TSN's national high school girls basketball rankings for the week of Monday, Nov. 25. Montverde Academy (FL) (2-0 – 2nd last week)The new-look Eagles opened the season with a 75-69 victory over Purcell Marian and cruised past Magnificat before departing Ohio. With Etiwanda going down, bumping the three-time defending Chipotle Nationals champion up to No. 1 was a fairly easy decision.  Ontario Christian (CA) (3-0 – 4th)More surprising than Ontario Christian’s upset over Etiwanda is the fact that plenty of scouts and media are still barely catching on to the Knights as national title heavyweights. Especially now that long-awaited freshmen Sydney Douglas and Tatianna Griffin have officially begun their high school careers – and are as good as promised. Douglas had 23 points, eight rebounds, and two blocks on 9-12 shooting in the 74-66 win against Etiwanda while Griffin registered a double-double.  Etiwanda (CA) (2-1 – 1st)The loss to Ontario Christian is Etiwanda’s first against a California opponent since before the 2023 state playoffs. But it was close, and there’s no need to sound the alarm – thanks largely to a second-half surge to make it close led by Grace Knox (30 points, 10 rebounds). It’s early, and Etiwanda will likely get cracks at Ontario Christian three months from now when championships are on the line. Before the loss, the Eagles posted statement wins against Corona Centennial and Sage Hill.  Princess Anne (VA) (0-0 – Bubble)Princess Anne was the last team left out of the top 25 in our preseason rankings, so they got first dibs on Legion Prep’s spot despite being yet to tip off. Fittingly, they Cavaliers are less than two weeks out from battling Thomas Dale, ranked one spot higher, for status as Virginia’s top team.Teams on the bubble:Boswell (TX)Centennial (NV)Clovis West (CA)DME Academy (FL)Loyola Academy (IL)Millard West (NE)Princess Anne (VA)Putnam City North (OK)St. Francis (GA)Whitney Young (IL)Winter Haven (FL) Lance has covered high school basketball, football and softball since 2019. A graduate of The USC Marshall School of Business, Smith dabbles in linear algebra and football and basketball computer rankings.

entry_title: In-Play Football Betting Hacks: Make Every Match a Payday!
entry_summary: If you’ve ever sat through a nail-biting football match, you know the thrill when the game suddenly flips—one goal, one card, or one substitution can change everything. Now imagine turning that adrenaline rush into a profitable moment with in-play betting. This isn’t some mystical art reserved for seasoned gamblers; it’s a game-changer for anyone who […]
entry_content: If you’ve ever sat through a nail-biting football match, you know the thrill when the game suddenly flips—one goal, one card, or one substitution can change everything. Now imagine turning that adrenaline rush into a profitable moment with in-play betting. This isn’t some mystical art reserved for seasoned gamblers; it’s a game-changer for anyone who knows football like the back of their hand. Buckle up, because you’re about to learn how to turn those live matches into serious cash with some insider hacks. First things first: ditch the pre-match bets if you want control. Pre-match betting is like throwing darts in the dark—sure, you might hit the bullseye, but it’s pure luck once the whistle blows. In-play betting, on the other hand, lets you react to real-time action. Is the underdog suddenly dominating possession? Is a star striker limping after a bad tackle? These are your golden nuggets of opportunity. Observing these micro-moments is where you gain an edge. One of my favorite hacks? Watch the live stats like a hawk. You don’t even need to be glued to the TV to spot opportunities. Possession stats climbing for a certain team? Shots on target piling up? A goal is brewing, my friend, and the odds might still be lagging behind. Jump on that next-goal market before the bookmakers catch up. Betting in real-time is like surfing—you ride the wave before it crashes. But here’s a truth bomb: emotions are your worst enemy. The moment you let a team’s colors or your undying loyalty cloud your judgment, you’re toast. Remember last season when your heart said Manchester United was going to turn it around against Brentford, but they were already 3-0 down at halftime? Yeah, that’s a mistake that cost thousands of fans money. Betting is about being cold, calculated, and ruthless. Forget your favorite team—your wallet doesn’t care about allegiances. Another killer strategy is to exploit the chaos. Injuries, red cards, and sudden momentum shifts are pure gold in in-play betting. For example, a red card changes everything. Suddenly, a team that was dominating might be scrambling to defend with ten men. This is your window to back the underdog or bet on fewer goals being scored. These moments are when the odds swing wildly, and quick decisions can net you big wins. Timing is everything. Bookmakers are quick, but they’re not perfect. Odds fluctuate in real time, and there’s often a brief delay before they adjust to a game-changing event. That delay is where savvy bettors pounce. If you can predict the shift—say, a star striker lining up for a free kick—you’ll lock in odds before they nosedive. Don’t ignore cash-out options either. Some people treat cash-out like a dirty word, but it’s a lifesaver when used right. Imagine you’ve bet on a team to win, and they’re up 2-1 in the 85th minute. The game’s heating up, and the opposition is pressing hard. Taking a cash-out here might save you from heartbreak (and an empty wallet) if the game ends in a draw. One more thing: know your limits. It’s easy to get sucked into the constant action of in-play betting. Every moment feels like it could be “the one,” but chasing losses or overloading on bets is a surefire way to crash and burn. Set a budget, stick to it, and don’t treat betting like a get-rich-quick scheme. Treat it like a calculated game of strategy, and you’ll keep your head above water. The beauty of in-play football betting is that it rewards those who know the game. It’s not about luck; it’s about being smarter, faster, and more analytical than the bookies. Whether you’re watching from the comfort of your couch or refreshing live stats on your phone, every match offers a hundred opportunities to profit. The only question is: are you ready to make every match a payday?

entry_title: Betting on the Premiership: The Do’s, Don’ts, and Profits
entry_summary: Betting on the Premiership isn’t just a casual hobby for football fans anymore—it’s become a battleground where strategy meets passion. The Premier League is like a treasure chest of potential winnings, but it’s also a minefield for anyone who dives in unprepared. You’ve probably heard the tales: the friend of a friend who turned a […]
entry_content: Betting on the Premiership isn’t just a casual hobby for football fans anymore—it’s become a battleground where strategy meets passion. The Premier League is like a treasure chest of potential winnings, but it’s also a minefield for anyone who dives in unprepared. You’ve probably heard the tales: the friend of a friend who turned a tenner into a few thousand on an outrageous accumulator, or the guy down the pub who “nearly” hit it big. For every win, there are countless losses, and if you’re not careful, you’ll end up as a statistic instead of a success story. First up, the do’s. Always—and I mean always—do your homework. Blindly betting on your favorite team is a rookie mistake that even seasoned bettors admit making early on. Sure, your loyalty to Manchester United might run deep, but if they’re up against a red-hot Arsenal side on a winning streak, you’ve got to put your emotions in a box and think like a strategist. Look at team form, injuries, head-to-head history, and even weather conditions. Yes, a slippery pitch can change everything when it comes to a fast-paced game like this. Another “do” is to shop around for the best odds. Bookies aren’t all created equal, and the difference between 3/1 and 5/1 might seem small, but over time, it can make or break your betting bankroll. Use odds comparison tools or keep tabs on multiple platforms. You wouldn’t buy a car without comparing prices—betting deserves the same attention. And speaking of bankroll, set one. It’s all too easy to keep chasing losses, throwing good money after bad. Decide how much you’re willing to lose before you start, and stick to it like glue. Now, let’s talk about the don’ts. Don’t let emotions cloud your judgment. Betting while angry after your team’s last-minute loss or overly excited because you’ve had a great week at work is a recipe for disaster. Betting should be cold, calculated, and clinical—not a reflection of your mood. And for heaven’s sake, don’t fall for the “sure thing” trap. Anytime someone promises a guaranteed win, run the other way. Upsets are as much a part of the Premier League as VAR controversies and dramatic stoppage-time goals. Betting is about probability, not certainty. One big “don’t” is to ignore smaller markets. Everyone flocks to bets like “who will win” or “first goalscorer,” but there’s value hiding in plain sight. Corners, yellow cards, and even the time of the first goal can be goldmines for those willing to dig. These markets are often less scrutinized by bookies, meaning there’s a better chance for savvy bettors to spot a weak line. Now, about the profits. Winning big on Premiership betting requires a mix of strategy and discipline. Accumulators, for instance, are tempting with their promise of massive payouts, but they’re also notoriously difficult to land. If you’re a thrill-seeker, limit your accas to smaller stakes while focusing the bulk of your bankroll on singles or doubles, where your odds of winning are much higher. Value betting is another key to profits—look for odds that don’t reflect the true probability of an event. Spotting these opportunities takes time and experience, but when you do, it’s like finding a hidden gem in the chaos of weekly fixtures. Live betting is another way to up your game, but it requires sharp instincts. Watching how a match unfolds in real-time can reveal opportunities you wouldn’t have considered before kickoff. For example, if a team’s star player goes off injured early, the dynamic changes instantly, and betting markets don’t always adjust quickly enough. The Premier League is as unpredictable as ever, which is exactly why betting on it is so exhilarating. But it’s not a free-for-all. Success comes down to discipline, research, and knowing when to walk away. Treat it like a game of chess, not roulette, and you’ll be on your way to turning your football knowledge into actual cash. And remember, the best bettors aren’t just lucky—they’re relentless in their pursuit of an edge. Are you ready to find yours?

entry_title: How to Spot the Best Value Bets in Football
entry_summary: When it comes to football betting, there’s one golden rule: don’t chase wins, chase value. The difference between casual punters and those who consistently come out on top lies in their ability to spot value bets. These aren’t just “good odds” or wagers that seem like sure things—they’re bets where the odds offered by the […]
entry_content: When it comes to football betting, there’s one golden rule: don’t chase wins, chase value. The difference between casual punters and those who consistently come out on top lies in their ability to spot value bets. These aren’t just “good odds” or wagers that seem like sure things—they’re bets where the odds offered by the bookmaker are higher than the true probability of the outcome. It’s not about gambling; it’s about finding an edge. So, how do you do it? Buckle up, because we’re about to dive into the nitty-gritty of value betting. Let’s start with the basics. A value bet exists when the implied probability of the bookmaker’s odds is lower than your estimated probability for an event. Say you’re betting on a match between Manchester City and West Ham. The bookie might offer 2.00 (evens) for a City win, implying a 50% probability. But you’ve done your homework, analyzed form, injuries, and head-to-head stats, and believe City’s actual chances of winning are closer to 65%. That’s a value bet staring you in the face, and it’s time to pounce. Homework is everything. Forget betting with your heart—this is science. Analyze recent performances, and don’t just focus on flashy scorelines. A team may have won their last three games, but if they’ve scraped through with late goals or were dominated in possession, the stats may paint a very different picture. Injuries, suspensions, and even travel schedules can tilt the scales dramatically, too. Football betting isn’t about hunches; it’s about data. Odds comparison tools are your new best friend. Bookmakers aren’t charitable organizations—they set odds to turn a profit. But not every bookmaker sees the game the same way. A bet that’s undervalued on one site might be a steal on another. By comparing odds across platforms, you can spot discrepancies that translate into value. It takes a bit of legwork, but when you see that one oddsmaker is offering 3.50 while the rest are at 3.20, you know where your money should go. Now, let’s talk implied probability. To calculate it, divide 1 by the decimal odds and multiply by 100. For example, odds of 2.50 imply a 40% chance of that event happening (1 ÷ 2.50 × 100 = 40). Once you’ve worked out the bookmaker’s implied probability, compare it to your assessment of the event. If your probability is higher, you’ve found value. If it’s lower, move on. This step separates pros from amateurs—it’s not glamorous, but it’s the cornerstone of consistent wins. Live betting is another playground for value hunters. Watching a match unfold gives you insights that static stats can’t. Maybe the favorite looks shaky under pressure, or an underdog is dominating the midfield. Bookmakers adjust live odds quickly, but not always accurately. If you’ve got a sharp eye and a quick trigger finger, you can exploit these moments for significant gains. Avoid the “trap” bets that bookies lay out like candy. Over hyped teams and popular bets often come with inflated odds because bookmakers know the masses will back them anyway. You’re not here to bet on the popular pick—you’re here to bet smart. If a line feels too good to be true, dig deeper. It might be a sign that the value lies elsewhere, like an underdog team quietly outperforming expectations. One thing that separates the serious bettor from the dreamer is discipline. Not every match has value, and that’s okay. Some weeks, you’ll scan the fixture list and find nothing worth your money. That’s the game. The key is to stick to your strategy, even if it means sitting on the sidelines while everyone else chases flashy accumulators and “guaranteed” wins. Value betting isn’t a sprint—it’s a marathon. You’re not here for quick hits; you’re here to build long-term success. Some bets will lose even when you’ve done everything right, but over time, the math works in your favor. It’s like fishing: you might not catch anything every time, but if you’ve got the best bait in the right spot, the big one will eventually bite. If there’s one takeaway here, it’s this: football betting isn’t about who wins or loses. It’s about identifying opportunities where the odds are in your favor and capitalizing on them. Anyone can place a bet, but spotting value? That’s the art and science that turns betting from a gamble into a strategy. So the next time you’re browsing odds for the weekend’s matches, don’t ask yourself, “Who’s going to win?” Instead, ask, “Where’s the value?

entry_title: Live Action, Big Wins: Best In-Play Betting Sites Ranked
entry_summary: In-play betting is where the true adrenaline junkies of the betting world thrive. Forget the hours of pre-match analysis—this is about making razor-sharp decisions in the heat of the moment. You’re watching the action unfold, reading the energy of the game, and pouncing on odds that shift like the tides. The right in-play betting site […]
entry_content: In-play betting is where the true adrenaline junkies of the betting world thrive. Forget the hours of pre-match analysis—this is about making razor-sharp decisions in the heat of the moment. You’re watching the action unfold, reading the energy of the game, and pouncing on odds that shift like the tides. The right in-play betting site can make or break your experience, and with so many platforms out there, finding the best can feel like searching for a needle in a haystack. But don’t worry, we’ve got you covered. Here are the top in-play betting sites that give you everything you need to turn live action into big wins. Bet365 is the undisputed heavyweight champ of in-play betting. It’s like the Swiss Army knife of sportsbooks, offering a mind-boggling array of live betting markets on everything from Premier League clashes to obscure volleyball matches in Kazakhstan. The live match visualizations are top-notch, giving you real-time stats and play-by-play updates to help you make quick decisions. But what truly sets Bet365 apart is its instant cash-out feature—perfect for locking in profits or cutting losses when things go sideways. If you’re all about user experience, Betway should be at the top of your list. Their in-play section is clean, intuitive, and lightning-fast. The odds update in real time without the frustrating lag you’ll find on some lesser platforms. Betway also has an edge in football and tennis, with a massive range of markets like next corner, break of serve, or even the next player to receive a yellow card. Plus, their Bet Builder lets you create customized wagers on the fly—a dream come true for live betting enthusiasts. Unibet is the dark horse of in-play betting. What it lacks in flashy branding, it makes up for in functionality and value. The platform specializes in niche sports and markets, making it a haven for bettors who prefer rugby, cricket, or even esports. The live streaming options are a standout feature here, often covering events other sites don’t. Being able to watch the action while placing bets gives you a massive edge in reading the game. William Hill is like that reliable old friend who never lets you down. Their in-play betting options are vast and cover virtually every sport under the sun. One of the best features is their Quick Bet function, which allows you to place bets in seconds—essential when odds are changing faster than a winger on a counter-attack. They’re also known for generous promotions tailored specifically for live bettors, so keep an eye out for free bets and cashback offers. Paddy Power is the joker of the pack, but don’t let their playful marketing fool you—they’re deadly serious about in-play betting. The site is particularly strong on football, offering quirky markets like who will score the next own goal or whether there will be a VAR decision. Their live chat and streaming features add a social element to betting, making it feel like you’re at the pub with your mates while placing your wagers. If you’re after in-play odds that give you real bang for your buck, 888Sport is a must-try. Their platform is slick, with live updates that don’t miss a beat. They excel in markets like basketball and American football, with deep stats to guide your decisions. The standout feature? Enhanced live odds on selected events—perfect for those who love a bargain. For those who want to level up their game, Betfair Exchange is the ultimate destination. It’s not a traditional sportsbook; instead, you’re betting against other punters, which often leads to better odds. The in-play exchange markets are a goldmine for sharp bettors who know how to exploit momentum swings. Plus, Betfair’s interface makes it easy to place bets or lay them off if you’re looking to hedge your bets mid-game. Coral might not grab headlines, but it’s quietly excellent at in-play betting. Their “Match Live” feature provides a blow-by-blow account of the action, and the odds refresh at breakneck speed. Coral is particularly strong on horse racing, so if you’re into live betting on the ponies, this is your go-to. Ladbrokes is all about reliability and simplicity. Their in-play markets are extensive, and they’re especially strong on major football leagues and tennis tournaments. The Ladbrokes Grid Card also gives you rewards for your bets, meaning you can rack up points for discounts and freebies. It’s a nice touch that makes every wager feel like it’s giving a little something back. If you’re in the U.S., DraftKings is your MVP for in-play betting. With a sleek app and a focus on American sports, it’s perfect for NFL, NBA, and MLB action. The stats they provide are unparalleled, and the live prop bets keep you engaged from the first whistle to the final buzzer. When it comes to in-play betting, the key is speed, versatility, and features that let you stay ahead of the game. Whether you’re a football fanatic or a fan of niche sports, the right platform can turn nail-biting moments into big payouts. Pick your site, sharpen your instincts, and get ready for the thrill ride that only live betting can deliver.

entry_title: The Best In-Play Football Bets That Guarantee Wins!
entry_summary: If you’re still stuck on pre-match bets, you’re missing out on the fast-paced, heart-pounding world of in-play football betting. Betting live during a match isn’t just about reacting to what’s happening—it’s about spotting patterns, reading the flow, and seizing opportunities before the odds adjust. Let’s break down the best in-play football bets that can seriously […]
entry_content: If you’re still stuck on pre-match bets, you’re missing out on the fast-paced, heart-pounding world of in-play football betting. Betting live during a match isn’t just about reacting to what’s happening—it’s about spotting patterns, reading the flow, and seizing opportunities before the odds adjust. Let’s break down the best in-play football bets that can seriously tilt the odds in your favor and help you walk away with a heavier wallet. First, let’s talk about next-goal markets. These are pure gold when you’ve got an eye for momentum shifts. Imagine this: the underdog suddenly takes control of possession, forcing a string of corners. You can feel a goal coming, but the bookmakers haven’t caught on yet. Betting on that next goal for the dominant team is one of the smartest moves you can make. Even better? If you’re watching live, those tiny details—a frustrated defense, a star player in form—give you an edge no algorithm can match. Another killer bet is the over/under goals market. This one’s especially profitable when the first half is a snooze fest. A slow first half often means the odds for over 1.5 or 2.5 goals shoot up. But here’s the thing: football is unpredictable, and the second half is where teams throw caution to the wind. Managers make aggressive substitutions, players get tired, and the goals start pouring in. Betting on more goals after a quiet start is a calculated risk that often pays off big. Now, let’s talk corners. Total corners bets are wildly overlooked, but they’re perfect for live betting. Watching a match and seeing relentless attacks or scrappy defending? Corners are bound to pile up. Keep an eye on attacking teams that like to take their chances from wide areas; they’ll rack up corners quickly. The same goes for underdog teams parking the bus—shots may get deflected for corners, creating a betting bonanza. Then there’s the drama of red cards. This is where quick reactions pay off. The moment a team loses a player to a red card, everything changes. Suddenly, the opposing team is in control, and goals could be on the horizon. Betting on a goal for the team with an advantage—or fewer goals overall if the leading team goes defensive—can be a jackpot. Red cards are chaos, and chaos is where you thrive in in-play betting. Don’t ignore both teams to score (BTTS), either. This market thrives on games that are end-to-end battles. Maybe the score is 1-1 in the 60th minute, and both teams are pressing hard. Odds for BTTS could still be decent if a third goal hasn’t landed yet. Watch for teams with leaky defenses and aggressive tactics—those matches scream goals on both sides. Now, for a sneaky one: cash-out strategies. Cash-out isn’t technically a bet, but it’s an art in live betting. Let’s say you’ve backed a team to win, and they’re leading 2-1 with ten minutes to go. The other side is attacking like their lives depend on it. That cash-out button? It’s your safety net. Taking the cash-out at the right moment can save you from last-minute heartbreak, especially in unpredictable leagues. Substitutions are another underutilized clue in in-play betting. Say the match is level, and a team brings on a star striker in the final 20 minutes. That’s your signal to look at markets like next goalscorer or the next team to score. Substitutions can shift the dynamic in seconds, and those who react fastest make the most profit. Finally, remember the timing of bets. Bookmakers are quick, but they aren’t flawless. Odds take a moment to update after a big event like a goal, red card, or even a VAR check. These windows, while small, are where you can exploit outdated odds. For example, a penalty awarded but not yet taken? The odds for a goal are still climbing while you lock in your bet. The beauty of in-play football betting is that it rewards sharp minds and quick fingers. You don’t need to be a mathematician; you just need to know the game and trust your instincts. By targeting next-goal markets, exploiting red card chaos, and watching for tactical shifts, you’ll put yourself in the driver’s seat. And while no bet is ever truly guaranteed, with these strategies, you’ll feel like you’ve got the upper hand every time the referee blows the whistle.

entry_title: Smart Tips for Betting on Sports and Beating the Odds
entry_summary: Betting on sports isn’t just about luck—it’s a skill, a blend of strategy, research, and discipline that separates consistent winners from those who are just chasing the thrill. If you’re tired of leaving your wagers to chance, it’s time to sharpen your approach with some smart tips for betting on sports and beating the odds. […]
entry_content: Betting on sports isn’t just about luck—it’s a skill, a blend of strategy, research, and discipline that separates consistent winners from those who are just chasing the thrill. If you’re tired of leaving your wagers to chance, it’s time to sharpen your approach with some smart tips for betting on sports and beating the odds. Let’s dive into the tips for betting on sports that can transform your bets into a more calculated and profitable endeavor. First things first: knowledge is power. Betting blindly on your favorite team because you’re emotionally invested is a recipe for disaster. You need to approach every bet with cold, hard logic. Start by researching the teams, players, and stats. Look at recent form, head-to-head records, injuries, and even the weather if it’s a factor. A bettor armed with data is far more dangerous than one relying on gut feelings. Speaking of odds, always shop around. Different bookmakers offer varying odds for the same events, and those slight differences can add up over time. Use odds comparison websites to find the best value for your bets. Remember, your goal is to get the most return for the risk you’re taking. Never settle for less when better odds are just a click away. Bankroll management is the cornerstone of smart sports betting. Set aside a specific amount of money for betting, and never exceed it. A good rule of thumb is to wager no more than 1-5% of your bankroll on a single bet. This strategy ensures you can weather losing streaks without going broke. Treat your bankroll like an investment fund—guard it with discipline and never bet impulsively. Avoid chasing losses. It’s easy to let frustration dictate your decisions after a string of bad bets. But doubling down in an attempt to recoup losses often leads to bigger mistakes. Stick to your strategy, and remember that sports betting is a marathon, not a sprint. Consistency is what builds long-term success. Diversify your bets. Sure, single bets on match outcomes are straightforward, but they’re not the only game in town. Explore other markets like over/under goals, player props, or handicap betting. These options can provide better value, especially in games where the outcome seems too close to call. And if you’re feeling adventurous, accumulators can offer big payouts—just remember, they’re high-risk and require all selections to hit. Live betting is another arena where smart bettors can gain an edge. Watching a game unfold in real time gives you insights that pre-match stats can’t provide. You might notice a team dominating possession or a key player struggling with form. Use this information to make more informed in-play bets. Just be cautious—live betting moves fast, so stay focused and avoid impulsive decisions. Know when to walk away. Sometimes, the smartest bet is the one you don’t place. If the odds don’t offer value, or if you’re unsure about an event, it’s better to pass. There’s always another game, another opportunity. Forcing bets out of boredom or desperation is a surefire way to drain your bankroll. Stay informed about promotions and bonuses. Many bookmakers offer free bets, enhanced odds, or cashback deals, especially for new customers. While these offers can’t guarantee wins, they’re great for reducing risk or increasing potential returns. Just make sure to read the terms and conditions—hidden restrictions can limit your ability to profit. Finally, keep your emotions in check. Betting is exciting, but it can also be frustrating when things don’t go your way. Remember, even the smartest punters don’t win every time. Success comes from sticking to your strategy, staying disciplined, and learning from both wins and losses. Betting on sports should be fun, but it’s also a test of patience and resilience. Smart sports betting isn’t about making reckless wagers in the heat of the moment. It’s about playing the long game, finding value, and managing your bankroll wisely. With these tips, you’ll be better equipped to beat the odds and enjoy the thrill of betting with a sharper edge.

entry_title: How the Odds Work in Betting and How to Calculate Payouts
entry_summary: Understanding how the odds work in betting is the key to becoming a smarter punter. Odds aren’t just random numbers—they reflect the bookmaker’s assessment of the likelihood of an outcome, while also determining how much you stand to win. Whether you’re a casual bettor or aiming to turn a profit, knowing how to read and […]
entry_content:
Understanding how the odds work in betting is the key to becoming a smarter punter. Odds aren’t just random numbers—they reflect the bookmaker’s assessment of the likelihood of an outcome, while also determining how much you stand to win. Whether you’re a casual bettor or aiming to turn a profit, knowing how to read and calculate payouts from odds can give you a significant edge. Let’s break it all down. Betting odds serve two purposes: they indicate the probability of an event happening and determine the payout you’ll receive if your bet wins. Different regions and platforms use different formats for odds, but the underlying principle remains the same. The three most common odds formats are: To calculate profit with decimal odds, use this formula:
Profit = (Odds x Stake) – Stake Odds also reflect implied probability, which is how likely a bookmaker thinks an outcome is. The lower the odds, the higher the perceived probability. For example: To calculate implied probability, use these formulas: For example: Bookmakers often build a margin (called the overround) into the odds to ensure they profit regardless of the outcome. This means the combined implied probabilities for all outcomes in a market will usually exceed 100%. Calculating your payout is crucial for managing your bets and spotting value. Here’s how to calculate total return and profit for each odds format: Understanding odds isn’t just about payouts; it’s also about spotting value. A value bet occurs when you believe an outcome is more likely than the odds suggest. For example, if a bookmaker offers odds of 3.00 (33.33% implied probability) on a team you estimate has a 50% chance of winning, that’s a value bet. Mastering how odds work and calculating payouts is essential for smart betting. Whether you’re using fractional, decimal, or American odds, the principles remain the same: understand the implied probability, calculate your potential return, and look for value. Armed with this knowledge, you’ll have a clearer path to smarter, more strategic wagers.

entry_title: Late-Game Heroics Sees Buffalo Sabres Topple Anaheim Ducks in Thrilling Overtime Encounter
entry_summary:
Buffalo Sabres Overcome Anaheim Ducks in Tense Overtime Clash

Friday night's NHL showdown saw Buffalo Sabres' Jiri Kulich steal the show, scoring an eleventh-hour goal with just under a minute left in overtime. This saw the Sabres rally back from trailing by two goals to clinch a 3-2 victory over the Anaheim Ducks.

Anaheim Ducks' Winning Streak Snapped by Buffalo Sabres

Kulich's crucial rebound shot, off an initial attempt by Sabres' defenseman Owen Power, found the top right corner of the net. This was Kulich's second goal of the season, marking a pivotal moment that ended the Ducks' three-game winning spree. Peyton Krebs and Jason Zucker, who are both in good form, also marked their names on the scoresheet for Buffalo, contributing to their second consecutive victory and their third in the last four games.

Power, who aided with two assists, along with goalie Ukko-Pekka Luukkonen's 23 saves, played a significant role in the Sabres' win. In contrast, Drew Helleson and Isac Lundestrom were the goal scorers for Anaheim, with their goalie, John Gibson, managing to block 31 shots.

Buffalo Sabres and Anaheim Ducks: Key Players and Moments

In the Sabres' camp, center Tage Thompson, leading the team with 11 goals and 18 points, missed his fourth consecutive game owing to a lower-body injury. However, Coach Lindy Ruff is optimistic about Thompson's return in their upcoming game against San Jose on Saturday.

For the Ducks, Trevor Zegras has been on a roll, tallying three assists in the last two games. A crucial turning point came when Krebs and Zucker netted two goals within a span of 50 seconds towards the end of the second period, leveling the game at 2-2. This marked the sixth instance of Buffalo scoring twice within a minute.

Zucker, who scored the equalizer with just 33 seconds left, now has goals in two successive games. Alex Tuch, who assisted Krebs’ goal, has managed to register points in five consecutive games, including a goal and six assists.

Key Statistics and What's Next?

Despite their win, Buffalo saw their seven-game power-play goal streak come to an end, which was the longest of any team this season. In terms of what's next, the Sabres are set to visit San Jose on Saturday, while the Ducks are due to host Seattle on Monday.

entry_title: Zary’s Decisive Strike Propels Calgary Flames to Victory Over New York Rangers
entry_summary:
Zary Seals Flames' Triumph, Rangers Suffer Second Road Loss

On a thrilling Thursday night, the Calgary Flames clinched a 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers, thanks to Connor Zary's crucial goal in the third period. Matt Coronato and Yegor Sharangovich contributed significantly with each adding a goal and an assist to the Flames' tally. MacKenzie Weegar demonstrated some impressive playmaking skills with three assists.

Jonathan Huberdeau Achieves Milestone, Dustin Wolf Shines Between the Pipes

Jonathan Huberdeau, another star for the Flames, hit a significant milestone by bagging his 500th career assist. In the net, Dustin Wolf stood tall, blocking 27 shots, marking his third consecutive victory.

For the Rangers, Alexis Lafreniere and Will Cuylle found the back of the net in a quick succession of just 16 seconds in the second period. Despite the loss, it's worth noting that this is only the second road game the Rangers have lost this season. Goalie Igor Shesterkin remained resilient, saving 46 shots.

Key Play: Zary's Game-Changing Goal

The game-changing moment came at 10:34 of the third period when Zary, who had been active on the ice throughout the game, shrugged off a challenge from Kaapo Kakko. He managed to lift the puck over Shesterkin, scoring what would be the game-winning goal.

Takeaways from the Game

The Flames showcased their best first period of the season, outshooting the Rangers 20-5. Despite this, they held only a slim one-goal lead heading into the second period. Their power play, which had been lackluster in November, came alive and produced an essential goal for the second game in a row.

The Rangers, on the other hand, relied heavily on their goalkeeper Shesterkin to keep them in the game. Their progress was hindered by four penalties within the first 29 minutes, stalling their momentum.

Breaking Down the Numbers

The Flames achieved a feat of 20-plus shots in the first period for the first time since October 25, 2022, when they registered a similar number against Pittsburgh.

What's Next for Flames and Rangers?

The Flames will be looking to continue their winning streak at home against the Minnesota Wild on Saturday. The Rangers will conclude their four-game road trip on the same day, facing off against the Edmonton Oilers.

entry_title: Blackhawks Soar to Victory: Mrazek and Teravainen Shine in 3-1 Triumph Over Panthers
entry_summary:
Chicago Blackhawks Overcome Florida Panthers in Thrilling 3-1 Encounter

Petr Mrazek's goaltending prowess was on full display as he thwarted 32 shots, while Teuvo Teravainen found the net, paving the way for the Chicago Blackhawks to soar past the Florida Panthers with a 3-1 victory on Thursday evening. Craig Smith and Nick Foligno also inked their names on the scoreboard, enabling Chicago to halt a hat-trick of consecutive losses. This victory also bolstered their home record to 3-5-0 for the season.

Mrazek's Impressive Return to Lineup

Mrazek made a triumphant return to the Blackhawks' lineup after sitting out Tuesday's 3-2 defeat to the Panthers due to personal reasons. He was a pivotal force in Chicago's victory, stopping numerous shots with impeccable skill and precision.

Teravainen's Power-Play Goal Sets the Tone

Teravainen set the Blackhawks on the path to victory with an early power-play goal, just 2:46 into the opening period. This marked only his second goal in his recent 17 appearances. Smith later doubled the lead, skillfully converting a breakaway into a goal, thanks to Pat Maroon's assist, 10:07 into the second period. This marked Smith's fifth goal for the campaign.

Reinhart's Lone Goal for Florida

Sam Reinhart, for the Panthers, managed to net his 15th goal of the season, marking his fourth in the last five games. Despite Florida's efforts to equalize in the final moments, Foligno sealed the deal for the Blackhawks with a decisive empty-netter with just a minute left on the clock.

Panthers' Missed Opportunities

Despite a couple of golden opportunities, the Panthers couldn't capitalize, leaving the ice empty-handed. The Stanley Cup champions, with Spencer Knight stopping 17 shots, experienced their fourth loss in five games.

Blackhawks' Resilient Response

Blackhawks' coach Luke Richardson was on the lookout for a more spirited performance from his team following their capitulation of a 2-1 lead in the third period against the Ducks. His team did not disappoint, presenting a resilient front, particularly in the game's final stages.

Key Moment of the Game

A noteworthy moment of the game came when Blackhawks' defenseman Wyatt Kaiser was benched for delay of game 12:22 into the third period. Despite this setback, the Blackhawks successfully killed off the penalty, rendering the Panthers' power-play opportunities futile.

Key Statistic

Foligno boasts an impressive record against Florida, with 10 goals and 14 assists to his name in his career against them.

What's Next?

The Panthers are set to kick off a three-game homestand against Colorado on Saturday night, while the Blackhawks will travel to Philadelphia for their next game on Saturday.

The post Blackhawks Soar to Victory: Mrazek and Teravainen Shine in 3-1 Triumph Over Panthers appeared first on 21Sports.com.

entry_title: Neighbours and Binnington Spearhead Blues’ Shootout Triumph over Sharks
entry_summary:
St. Louis Blues Snatch Victory from Sharks, Putting an End to Home Losing Streak

Jake Neighbours emerged as the shootout star, while Jordan Binnington defied all three attempts by the San Jose Sharks, leading the St. Louis Blues to a 3-2 triumph on Thursday night. This win ended a four-game home losing streak for the Blues. Binnington displayed resilience by bouncing back from Alexander Wennberg's equalizing goal with only 8.8 seconds remaining, securing his 151st career victory. This tied him with Mike Liut's franchise record.

Standout Performances

Wennberg was the lone double-goalscorer for the Sharks, with Mikael Granlund and Macklin Celebrini, the 2024 NHL draft's top pick, providing assists for both goals. For the Blues, Jordan Kyrou and Nathan Walker found the back of the net during regulation time. This marked only the second victory in their last nine matches.

Walker's goal came just 11 seconds into the game, thanks to Radek Faksa's interception of a pass from Sharks' goalie Yaroslav Askarov. Later, Kyrou, positioned between Granlund and Timothy Liljegren, nudged home a pass from Pierre-Olivier Joseph for his sixth goal of the season, with 8:13 remaining in the second.

Goalkeeper Highlights

Binnington held the fort with 22 saves, contributing significantly to the Blues' victory, while Askarov managed 29 saves.

Key Takeaways

The Sharks, who have been outscored 28-10 in the season's first period, struggled from the onset, despite netting a first-period goal for the third consecutive game. On the other hand, Binnington, with 295 games under his belt, stands second among goalies in Blues' franchise history. He reached the 151-win milestone in 56 fewer games than Liut, whose record from 1979-1985 stood at 151-133, with 52 ties.

Game-Changing Moment

Neighbours played the hero, delivering the shootout victory with a wrist shot that outsmarted Askarov on his glove side.

Key Statistics

The Blues have been outscored 14-2 in the third period across their last seven games.

What's Next?

The Blues are set to play seven out of their next eight games on the road, commencing Saturday against the New York Islanders. The Sharks, on the other hand, will start a four-game homestand against Buffalo the same day.

The post Neighbours and Binnington Spearhead Blues’ Shootout Triumph over Sharks appeared first on 21Sports.com.

entry_title: Blue Jackets’ Epic Battle: A Stunning Overtime Victory Over Lightning
entry_summary:
Werenski's Overtime Goal Brings Columbus Blue Jackets a Remarkable Comeback Victory

Zach Werenski's masterstroke at 1:25 of the overtime session marked the climax of a thrilling game as the Columbus Blue Jackets overcame a three-goal deficit to triumph over the Tampa Bay Lightning, in an electrifying 7-6 victory on Thursday night. Werenski, shining in the spotlight, equalized the game at 4 in the second period and contributed with three assists, helping the Blue Jackets secure their second consecutive win.

Key Players in the Clash

Sean Monahan and Dmitri Voronkov greatly supported their team with a goal and three assists and a goal plus an assist, respectively. Kent Johnson, returning from an injury hiatus that had sidelined him for 14 games, made his mark with a power play and a short-handed goal. Yegor Chinakhov added another goal to the tally while Elvis Merzlikins showcased his goalkeeping skills by blocking 24 shots.

For the Lightning, Anthony Cirelli, Mitchell Chaffee, Brandon Hagel, and Connor Geekie all performed valiantly, each securing a goal and an assist. Brayden Point and Cam Atkinson also added to the scoresheet, with Nikita Kucherov assisting thrice. Jonas Johansson showed resilience with 36 saves.

Game Highlights

Despite Tampa Bay's seemingly smooth sailing after netting three early goals, they couldn't sustain their lead. The Blue Jackets, back on their home turf after seven out of their last eight games on the road, retaliated fiercely with four goals in the second period.

The game's pivotal moment was undoubtedly when Tampa Bay, leading by three goals in the first period, found themselves under fire in the second period. Columbus turned the tables, scoring four times and Tampa only twice.

Notable Stats

Brayden Point, in his second game after a four-match absence due to a lower-body injury, scored a power-play goal just 23 seconds into a Columbus penalty, at 1:51 of the first period. Point has now netted three times in two games, tying with Nikita Kucherov for the team lead with 11.

What's Next?

Both teams will return to the ice on Saturday night. The Lightning will face Dallas at home, while the Blue Jackets prepare to host Carolina.

The post Blue Jackets’ Epic Battle: A Stunning Overtime Victory Over Lightning appeared first on 21Sports.com.

entry_title: Colorado’s Victory Over Washington: A Glimpse Into the Post-Ovechkin Era?
entry_summary:
Colorado Avalanche Triumphs Over Washington Capitals in Nail-Biting Encounter

Miles Wood Fires Avalanche to Victory

In an electrifying Thursday night showdown, Colorado Avalanche clinched a tight 2-1 win over Washington Capitals, with Miles Wood playing the hero as his third-period goal became the decider. Mikko Rantanen, another Avalanche star, also found the net, marking the team's fifth victory in their last six outings.

Alexandar Georgiev Continues Winning Streak

Alexandar Georgiev, the formidable Avalanche goaltender, demonstrated his mettle with an awe-inspiring performance that saw him repel 29 shots. This marked his fourth consecutive win after returning from an upper-body injury that sidelined him for two games.

Capitals Feel the Absence of Ovechkin

For the Capitals, it was Pierre-Luc Dubois who scored, but the team's winning spree came to an abrupt end, halting at three victories. Logan Thompson, the Capitals goalkeeper, experienced his maiden regulation loss of the season with 25 saves. Earlier, the team was dealt a significant blow as Alex Ovechkin, their superstar, was ruled out for four to six weeks due to a broken left fibula, sustained during their Monday clash against Utah.

Avalanche's Takeaways

Despite Nathan MacKinnon failing to score for the second time in three games — both against the Capitals — Rantanen maintained his impressive form, securing points in five of his last six games.

Capitals' Takeaways

Without Ovechkin's presence, the Capitals found it difficult to generate momentum offensively. Their usually effective power play, often energized by their captain, went 0 for 2.

Key Moment of the Match

The defining moment came just 3:29 into the third period when Wood, positioned at the front of the net, deflected Cale Makar's point shot, sending it past Thompson for the lead.

Crucial Statistic

A telling statistic dating back to the 2021-22 season reveals that the Capitals have a dismal 4-14 record without Ovechkin in the team. At the time of his injury, the captain was leading the league with 15 goals, only 27 short of Wayne Gretzky's record.

What's Next?

The Avalanche is set to square off against the reigning Stanley Cup champions, Florida, on Saturday, while the Capitals will host New Jersey.

The post Colorado’s Victory Over Washington: A Glimpse Into the Post-Ovechkin Era? appeared first on 21Sports.com.

entry_title: Golden Knights Overcome Senators in Thrilling Skirmish, with Samsonov’s Stellar Performance in the Net
entry_summary:
Golden Knights Prevail Over Senators in Hard-Fought Match

In a hockey game that kept fans on the edge of their seats, the Vegas Golden Knights claimed victory over the Ottawa Senators with a nail-biting 3-2 score on Thursday night. Ilya Samsonov, who had let in 10 goals over his last two games, bounced back with a remarkable performance, pulling off 38 saves.

Samsonov's Key Saves Halt Senators' Attack

Despite the Senators' aggressive play, Samsonov held strong, making crucial saves against formidable players like Josh Norris, David Perron, Tim Stutzle, and Brady Tkachuk. The Senators (8-10-1) find themselves trapped in a four-game losing streak, having scored just two goals throughout their last three games.

Golden Knights Gain the Upper Hand

In the initial phase of the game, the Golden Knights (12-6-2) seized control when Linus Ullmark made a spectacular diving save but failed to reposition quickly enough. This left Jack Eichel with an unhindered shot to the net, marking his sixth goal this season. Brett Howden extended their lead to 2-0 in the mid-second period, slipping a goal past Ullmark, who had 29 saves in the game.

Sensational Third-Period Action

Adam Gaudette managed to get one past Samsonov 7:17 into the third period, narrowing the lead. However, the Senators' joy was short-lived as Pavel Dorofeyev restored the two-goal lead just two minutes later. Drake Batherson kept the Senators' hopes alive, scoring a goal off a Jake Sanderson rebound with a little over seven minutes left. Despite the Senators outshooting the Golden Knights 18-5 in the third period, they fell short of a comeback.

Key Takeaways and Statistics

A recurring issue for the Senators has been their habit of conceding the first goal, which has led to eight consecutive losses and a dismal 1-9-1 record when they let in the first goal. On the other hand, the Golden Knights capitalized on an ill-timed Ottawa line change, delivering a swift counter-strike leading to Howden's goal. The Golden Knights have an impressive 12-1-1 track record against the Senators since their entry into the league in 2017.

What's Next for Both Teams?

Looking ahead, the Senators are gearing up to host the Vancouver Canucks on Saturday night, while the Golden Knights prepare to face off against the Montreal Canadiens on Saturday afternoon.

The post Golden Knights Overcome Senators in Thrilling Skirmish, with Samsonov’s Stellar Performance in the Net appeared first on 21Sports.com.
